posts.name: Ezriel Nagaokar
posts.cooked: Hi, I wanna start my own project and cad a full robot alone, I want carbon tubes in my robot, how did you make carbon tubes joints in your robot ? Tnx!

posts.name: Sam Dare
posts.cooked: We will be releasing our cad very shortly with examples of this, but we printed onyx end plugs with glue grooves and hot glued them in. Ideally no drilling through carbon fiber tubes, but we had to this year in one location. I’ll edit and send a picture when I get a sec because it’s way easier to visualize with a picture.

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked: For 1678 in 2019 we made aluminum sockets for our lifting forks. Carbon rods were epoxied into the sockets after the aluminum parts were soaked in a highly concentrated Lye solution for a few minutes to heavily etch the surfaces. Never had the glue break free all season.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
Back in 2018, we made a set of “support forks” (a/k/a the “spork”) out of square carbon fiber tubes.  The joints were done with carbon fiber gusset plates on both sides, applied with high grade epoxy and quickly riveted together before the epoxy set up.  The process was time-critical and a bit nerve-wracking but we did not have any failures.

I don’t think I have any pictures readily accessible at the moment but I can take some next time I’m at our shop if people are interested.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Only thing was getting any dust out of the tube when I was involved. Gentle preheating of the tube with a hot air gun on low and of the part gives the glue a little more working time. (reverse that process to get it apart, major win over epoxy there)

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked:
Warning, I’m going to say something crazy:

Hot glue does not stick to CF nearly as well as epoxy made to stick to CF.  If you are able to work and wiggle the joint long enough and with enough force, while putting it under enough tension, you can get the bond to fail.

This being said, you would be surprised at how many joints don’t fall into this category OR can be designed such that it isn’t a problem.  Some might say “Well, you are crazy! Why choose the inferior hot glue joint over epoxy?”  Here’s a few reasons:

Ease of assembly.  No mixing. No epoxy mess. Just heat, glue, push together.

Ease of disassembly.  Made a mistake with that expensive CF tube, just gently heat it up with a heat gun and it comes apart.

Ease of reassembly.  Do # 2 in the reverse order.

Reuse of CF tube.  Disassemble old revisions to reuse the tube.

I would scratch/rough up the tube and clean it before gluing but to be honest we are lax at following this procedure.  I believe 2337s arm was hot glued together.  They did prep the surface and had a healthy amount surface area and insertion depth.  They reported no failures.  We have had some failures, but we addressed them by pinning the joint.

Also, cool hot glue tech tip:  Use alcohol to loosen/remove hot glue from a smooth surface.  I don’t know how it works but spray the glue with alcohol and let it sit for a minute.  It won’t attack the glue but seems to seep into the glue/surface interface and messes with the bond.  60% of the time, it works every time.

posts.name: Ronnie Sherrer
posts.cooked:
+1. We also do generally this. On a few that we have noticed issues or would have been an issue, we added a clamping mechanism (3D Printed SLS or Onyx) with the plug. It was a pretty happy switch from epoxy to hot glue for us. Would recommend it again as long as you understand where it will and won’t work.

-Ronnie

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked:
Yeah, those renders are not what I was referring to unfortunately.

i-GGqNtfG-X3 1600×1067 144 KB

i-GGqNtfG-X3 1600×1067 144 KB

i-GGqNtfG-X3 1600×1067 144 KB

This is the Carbon rod thingy. The joints that have glue are the double sockets and top bar, plus the single sockets on the bottom cross bar. The bottom cross bar also has a clamping screw where the doubles go through it and were HEAVILY rounded at the edges to reduce piont loads that can damage the CF rod.

I also just realized I should talk about our 2015 can grabber/2023 fork holding method. i-GwVNsZN-X3 1600×1067 167 KB If you look at the forks there is a sheet metal piece wrapped around the base of the CF tube, in 2015 it was 0.032" and for 2023 it was 0.063" and we had to make a custom forming die to make the ones this year. There is a thin sheet of rubber between the CF tube and the metal to prevent point loads at the spot where the tube comes out and hold it securely, this was super important in 2015 with how hard we were slamming the can grabbers. For 2023 we decided to recycle the basic concept because we knew it would work and would properly protect the CF tube from point load damage. The sheet part is not easy to make, the one in 2015 was made over a form rod with a hammer, vise grips, and some swearing. Could probably be done well with some clever 3D print instead by using some clamps to form it.

i-GwVNsZN-X3 1600×1067 167 KB

i-GwVNsZN-X3 1600×1067 167 KB

posts.name: Sam Dare
posts.cooked:
image 555×651 63.9 KB Here is a picture of our elevator carriage with a good look at our “glue grooves” - as Mark said, hot glue is not a magic bullet. We love the ability to quickly iterate by heating things up. Here’s an example.

image 555×651 63.9 KB

image 555×651 63.9 KB

For the first part of the season, when we needed to change that gearbox on our elevator, we had to heat up the elevator and pull it apart to access the carriage. Then we had to pull apart the carriage, slide off the old gearbox, and slide the new one on. Then we heated the plugs back up, added more glue where needed, and put the thing back together. This process was much faster than rebuilding the entire elevator like we may have had to with a full epoxy assembly. Of course, this is different if you don’t have an all carbon fiber elevator. Later in the season, we pivoted to a bolt on approach for the arm gearboxes to be able to iterate on that assembly quicker.

Key thing with the hot glued joints is to know what kinds of loads are trying to shear the glue joint, and to know if those forces are relatively high. If they are, some clamping element can also be helpful. We did this on our arm by making it two pieces that bolt together, like @RonnieS said. Even with clamping elements, we ended up having the joint come loose, so we lengthened the joint to increase the surface area of the clamp to strengthen the glue interface.

One more thing - when heating up, you can be too aggressive with the heat gun and melt the printed parts, so watch out for that, too.

TLDR; hot glue is not perfect for this application, but it is really good.

posts.name: Royce F.

I learned this from 4613, they used clamping force to joint carbon fiber tubes together on their 2023 robot. This meathod seems to be the most simple way of doing it.
